title: using SAS in Quarto
text:
SASmarkdown package
SASmarkdown package supports using SAS in Rmarkdown or Quarto files

library(SASmarkdown)
library(knitr)



Settings for SAS

saspath <- "E:/Program Files/SASHome/SASFoundation/9.4/sas.exe"
sasopts <- "-nosplash -ls 75"
opts_chunk$set(
  engine.path = list(sas = saspath, saslog = saspath),
  engine.opts = list(sas = sasopts, saslog = sasopts),
  comment = NA
)

encoding="gbk" allows outputs containing Chinese characters, otherwise the Chinese characters could be messy.

proc print data=sashelp.class;
run;
##            观测    Name          Sex    Age    Height    Weight

objectID: posts/number of events needed in survival analysis/index.html
href: posts/number of events needed in survival analysis/index.html
title: number of events needed in survival analysis
text:
library(gsDesign)
## Loading required package: ggplot2
## Warning: package 'ggplot2' was built under R version 4.2.3
rm(list = ls())

using the nEvents function from gsDesign to calculate the number of events

(nE <- nEvents(hr = 0.6, alpha = 0.025, beta = 0.2))
## [1] 120.3157

the \(log(HR)\) under null distribution~\(N(0, \frac{1}{d_1} + \frac{1}{d_2})\). To control for the type 1 error no more than one sided 0.025, we could derived the critical value for significance test.
The variance of \(log(HR)=\frac{1}{d_1} + \frac{1}{d_2}\) was derived based on exponential distribution, using the maximum likelihood method to estimate the parameter:
First, considering one treatment setting \[Likelihood=\prod_{i=1}^{n}f(t)^{\delta_i}S(t)^{1-\delta_i}\] where n is size all subjects; if the subject occur event, then \(\delta_i=1\); f(t) is the probability density function of survival time, and S(t) is the survival function.

d <- nE
z_cut <- qnorm(
  p = 1 - 0.975,
  mean = 0,
  sd = sqrt(4 / d)
)
z_cut
## [1] -0.357369

Under the alternative hyperthesis, the \(log(HR)\) obeys distribution of \(N(log(hr), \frac{1}{d_1} + \frac{1}{d_2})\). Here we also used the standard distribution under null hyperthesis as other statistic software (e.g, EAST).

pnorm(
  q = z_cut,
  mean = log(0.6),
  sd = sqrt(4 / d)
)
## [1] 0.8

The variance of log(hr) \(\frac{1}{d_1} + \frac{1}{d_2}\) could also be expressed:
\[\frac{1}{r(1-r)D}\] where D is the total number events of control and active treatments, r is the event proportion from control treatment.

# control / event
(nE <- nEvents(hr = 1.4, alpha = 0.025, beta = 0.2, ratio = 0.5))
## [1] 311.9764


d <- nE
r <- 1 / 3
sd <- sqrt(1 / (r * (1 - r) * d))

z_cut <- qnorm(
  p = 0.975,
  mean = 0,
  sd = sd
)
z_cut
## [1] 0.235393


1 - pnorm(
  q = z_cut,
  mean = log(1.4),
  sd = sd
)
## [1] 0.8

title: Critical value for two correlated endpoints
text:
library(tidyverse)

Warning: package 'tidyverse' was built under R version 4.2.2


── Attaching packages ─────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse 1.3.2 ──
✔ ggplot2 3.3.6      ✔ purrr   0.3.4 
✔ tibble  3.1.8      ✔ dplyr   1.0.10
✔ tidyr   1.2.1      ✔ stringr 1.4.1 
✔ readr   2.1.2      ✔ forcats 0.5.2 
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()

library(mvtnorm)
rm(list = ls())


solve_z <- function(z) {
  1 - pmvnorm(lower = c(-Inf, -Inf), 
              upper = c(z, z), 
              mean = c(0, 0), 
              corr = matrix(c(1, 0.9, 0.9, 1), nrow = 2, byrow = T)) - 0.025
}

root <- uniroot(f = solve_z, interval = c(0.01, 5))$root
1 - pnorm(q = root)

[1] 0.01750927



solve_z <- function(z) {
  1 - pmvnorm(lower = c(-z, -z), 
              upper = c(z, z), 
              mean = c(0, 0), 
              corr = matrix(c(1, 0.8, 0.8, 1), nrow = 2, byrow = T)) - 0.10
}

root <- uniroot(f = solve_z, interval = c(0.01, 5))$root
1 - pnorm(q = root)

[1] 0.0324447

title: plot epplipse
text:
mixtools package
using the ellipse function in mixtools package to generate ellipse data

library(mixtools)
## Warning: package 'mixtools' was built under R version 4.2.2
## mixtools package, version 2.0.0, Released 2022-12-04
## This package is based upon work supported by the National Science Foundation under Grant No. SES-0518772 and the Chan Zuckerberg Initiative: Essential Open Source Software for Science (Grant No. 2020-255193).
library(ggplot2)
## Warning: package 'ggplot2' was built under R version 4.2.3
rm(list = ls())

the parameter of ellipse function are means and standard deviations of multivariate normal distribution

mu <- c(1, 3)
sigma <- matrix(c(1, 0.3, 0.3, 1.5),
  nrow = 2, ncol = 2,
  byrow = T
)
e <- ellipse(mu, sigma, npoints = 250, draw = F)
e <- as.data.frame(e)


ggplot(data = e, aes(x = V1, y = V2)) + 
  geom_path()

title: Critical value for two correlated endpoints
text:
Calculate sample size

one
two


SampleSize <- getSampleSizeMeans(
  alpha = 0.025,
  beta = 0.2,
  sided = 1,
  groups = 2,
  alternative = 2,
  stDev = 3.5,
  allocationRatioPlanned = 1
)
SampleSize

Design plan parameters and output for means:

Design parameters:
  Critical values                              : 1.96 
  Significance level                           : 0.0250 
  Type II error rate                           : 0.2000 
  Test                                         : one-sided 

User defined parameters:
  Alternatives                                 : 2 
  Standard deviation                           : 3.5 

Default parameters:
  Mean ratio                                   : FALSE 
  Theta H0                                     : 0 
  Normal approximation                         : FALSE 
  Treatment groups                             : 2 
  Planned allocation ratio                     : 1 

Sample size and output:
  Number of subjects fixed                     : 98.1 
  Number of subjects fixed (1)                 : 49.1 
  Number of subjects fixed (2)                 : 49.1 
  Critical values (treatment effect scale)     : 1.403 

Legend:

title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
This is the first post in a Quarto blog. Welcome!

Since this post doesn’t specify an explicit image, the first image in the post will be used in the listing page of posts.
